Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 07:37PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I will tell you what my best friend did for me. Every day, she listened to my fears. She gave me hugs when I was upset and a shoulder to cry on, and she made me laugh when my mood was lighter. She let me know if my behavior was erratic (the steroids made me crazy). She reached into the abyss and pulled me out numerous times when my faith faltered. She was my nightlight on the dark side of the moon and the calm and the rock in my very turbulent storm. She reminded me that the treatments and cancer would be over before long, and that I would have a normal life again. The two most important things she did was to assure me that she would be with me throughout the ordeal, no matter how long it took, and that she would not let me lose hope. I'm a very strong person, but I have no doubt that I couldn't have done this without her, or at least, come through it with my sanity intact. I owe her my life.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2009 11:33AM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I wanted my ovaries removed for two reasons: 1) to decrease estrogen levels and 2) even though I'm BRCA1&2 negative, my mother died of bc and her sister of ovarian cancer, so there may be a genetic factor to my cancer. I'm 49, so I was pretty close to natural menopause. According to my onc, my body had received about all the benefits it was going to from the hormones and chemicals produced from my ovaries, so there was no big advantage to leaving the potential trouble-makers in there. And estrogen certainly hasn't been my friend lately. If I were younger, having my ovaries removed may have increased my chances for future heart problems, Parkinson's disease, etc. The best you can do is research the pros and cons of an oophorectomy and make your decision on what you're comfortable with. As for the oophorectomy itself, it was a rather trouble-free procedure for me. I had a mild level of pain for about four days. I was back at work in five days. I went hiking 12 days after the procedure. My hot flashes have intensified a little, but they're still quite tolerable. And I don't have to worry about getting ovarian cancer now.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 09:06AM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I had 6 infusions of TAC chemo prior to radiation. I breezed through it. I began taking Tamoxifen a week prior to rads. I had 25 rads with 5 boosts over a 6-week period. I didn't start feeling tired until the end of week four. Then I learned what fatigue was all about! I was fatigued for about 5-6 weeks. I was able to take 2 weeks off work at Christmas (fortunately), and during the first week, I slept or rested most of the week. By the second week off, my energy level was returning to normal, and I was up and about, taking long walks and hiking again. I've felt great ever since. During the 5-6 weeks of radiation fatigue, I also received a Zometa infusion, had a staph infection, and sinus drainage, so I'm sure these caused me to feel even more run down.

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 12:37PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: Hi, debisongbird, I finished radiation about 6 weeks ago now, and I had it in all the places you mentioned but on both the left and right sides. My radiation onc said I might lose some lung capacity, but it wouldn't be noticible and wouldn't interfere with my ability to hike and long-distance bicycle. She didn't think it would damage my heart at all. About a week after the completion of radiation, I had an echocardiagram (due to having a staph infection, not radiation), and the cardialogist said my heart was fine.  Now that I'm recovering from the fatigue (I'll get to that later), I'm back to hiking and haven't suffered any shortness of breath. My radiation onc did say that, in the future, if I get a chest xray to mention to the radiologist that I've had radiation because some scarring will show up on the xray. I came through fine with no signs of lymphedema. Fatigue...boy, howdy, for the first time in my life I knew what it felt like to be tired! I've always been the Energizer Bunny, even at age 49, but I became more like a hibernating bear for about a month. I still managed to go to work and run errands during radiation, but not much else. However, the natural fatigue from radiation, for me, was probably worsened by having an infected portacath (ergo, the staph infection), starting Tamoxifen, receiving my first infusion of Zometa, and sinus drainage. But I'm back to bouncing off the walls again! LOL! Skin care...I mixed pure aloe vera gel with Aquafor and used that in the morning; after receiving radiation, I put on pure aloe vera gel; then I rubbed in emu oil at bedtime. I had painful burns under my arms for about a week; chest didn't burn much, but I did peel in those places. I'm fair-skinned, and my redness is almost gone. I continue to use emu oil to keep the radiated skin soft. My skin never "broke down" and got oozy. Hope that helps!

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2008 10:17AM Celtic_Spirit wrote: Hi! I've been lurking here for a while, but this post prompted me to sign up. During my darkest time, when I felt sure I was going to die from breast cancer (post-stage IIIa diagnosis and in the middle of chemo), my boyfriend's 85-year-old mother told me this story about her sister, Evelyn. Evelyn was diagnosed in the early 1970s, at age 49 (my age) with what was probably stage III cancer. She had a large lump and lots of positive nodes. Evelyn had a radical mastectomy and...nothing else. No chemo, no rads, no tamoxifan, no alternative therapies, etc. Evelyn is now in her early 80s. She's had some health problems, like all people in their 80s (pericarditis, arthritis), but her breast cancer never returned. I have met Evelyn on several occasions, and I can tell you she is robust and overall in good shape for a lady of her years. For those of you who have seen "Fried Green Tomatoes," remember how Kathy Bates' character used "Towanda" as her battle cry? Well, "Evelyn" is my breast cancer battle cry. This story lifted me out of my BC depression and continues to inspire me. I hope it helps you, too.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2009 02:26PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: When I was sweating the statistics back in the summer of 2008, my best friend, who's a nurse, said, "You're lumped in with the 85-year-olds, the alcoholics, the morbidly obese, the smokers, the diabetics, the malingerers, the women with more aggressive forms of bc, and those in poor health to start with. They don't have a separate category for you." That became a mantra I repeated over and over when I felt scared. Having worked in academic publishing, I can tell you that an article or report that is printed today was submitted 6-24 months ago. The writers spent at least six months to a year compiling the data and writing it up. Before that, they spent 5-10 years following the test subjects. So we're talking about treatments and technologies that were used, at a minimum, six years ago, and more likely eight. During my first meeting with my onc, she said that I had a 30% chance that the cancer would recur in five years, and that was using the numbers from the low end of the scale. That was before she prescribed me zometa, before I began taking Vitamin D3, before she knew how much I exercised (3-5 hrs. a week can cut your recurrence numbers in half), and before my oophorectomy. I'm betting my worst-case recurrence rate is down to about 10% now. Something else to consider: some people are not compliant with treatment. In an article on the Susan G. Komen for the Cure site, 37% of women taking tamoxifen are non-compliant (here's the link: http://ww5.komen.org/ExternalNewsArticle.aspx?newsID=42817). I imagine the same is true for those taking AIs. Those folks are also lumped into the general statistics.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2009 03:21PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I second what cbm said about steroids. Decadron was like an amplifier for every fear, every negative notion I had. I could read a death-sentence into every comment and every raised eyebrow. Like DCMom, my chemo days were more like going to a salon. It was three days after that the trouble began due to the steroids. Before each infusion, I would tell my boyfriend and my best friend to put on their catchers mitts and get out the butterfly nets because I was going to be wild and woolly and out of my mind. Have some kind of distraction. And know that it's perfectly normal to be hyperemotional right now and assume the worst. It goes with the territory.

I live in a hot climate and don't find that they make me uncomfortable; in fact, my natural breasts were large and uncomfortable, and in the summer I got rashes beneath them and lots of sweat. These are a breeze compared to my real breasts!

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2012 12:49PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: My oncologist is a very kind and positive person. Had I asked for a referral to a support group, I'm sure she would have given me one. But I'm not a support group type of gal...I find that hysteria feeds into hysteria, and I didn't need anyone else ramping me up even more. The decadron did a stellar job of that on its own. My onc didn't hesitate when I asked her for some xanax, though, and that certainly helped me cope! I was treated through my HMO. I realized even then that my doctors and nurses barely had time to treat the disease, let alone address any personal crises I was having. They see so many patients each day, and many of them, I'm sure, were in far more distress than I was. I'm wagering a guess here, but I bet that, to some degree, they do see us as a particular disease/cancer. Oncologists and surgeons are trained to fight that disease. Psychologists are taught to treat the psyche. Just recently, during a routine appointment, I asked my gynecological oncologist about a patch of dry skin I had, and I might as well have asked him to explain nuclear fusion! Just not his area. So if you are in need of counseling or a support group, speak up! Or, if you have difficulty doing that, is there someone--a friend, a spouse, a relative--who could act as your patient advocate? As far as what I did to cope (other than xanax), I shared my fears with my closest friends and my boyfriend, took long walks and hikes, kept busy, and always kept sight of my goals. I told myself daily this was only a short chapter in my life, and everyone has these dark chapters, and things would be back to normal (at least close to normal) before long. And that's exactly how everything played out.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 01:45PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I worked throughout my six weeks of radiation, which ran from mid-October 2008 to Thanksgiving. I'm a desk jockey in an isolated office, so I didn't have the stress of office politics to deal with or physical considerations. The radiation facility was half-way between work and home, so I stopped in on my way home from work. I felt pretty good for the first four weeks of rads; then the fatigue set in. My skin was also getting rather crispy around this time. After rads each day, I went home and slept. I had some vacation time to use up (or lose) by the end of the year, so I took two weeks off around Christmas. I slept the entire first week. Then I started getting my energy back. By New Year's Day, I was hiking in the mountains. The two weeks I spent taking it easy may have prevented the long-term fatigue that a lot of ladies suffer from. I've been high energy ever since.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 09:16AM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I was your children's age when my mother had breast cancer during the 1960s. That was during the era when children were excluded from "adult" conversations. I have mixed feelings about that. I knew my mother was sick. I knew she had cancer. I had no idea it was terminal. I knew about death, as my father had died of a brain tumor when I was six. However, day-to-day life was pretty normal and happy for me, perhaps because I wasn't burdened with all the details. My mother was admitted to the hospital for the last time in December 1969. A week before she died, my aunt told me the whole truth...that my mom's cancer had gotten worse, that it had spread elsewhere in her body, and that she was dying. I felt like I had been hit by a truck. I suddenly had visions of myself as Oliver Twist, which as it turned out wasn't too far from the truth, but that's another story. I alternated between feeling terrified and being numb. Now that I'm an adult with breast cancer myself, I wish I had more information about my mother's cancer (all of my aunts, uncles, and mother's friends have also passed - no one left to ask). I can't remember if she had her hysterectomy before or after the cancer or why. I don't know if she had lymph nodes involved. I'm not sure where her cancer metastasized to. She was diagnosed before the days of chemotherapy and hormonals and only received surgery and a crude form of radiation that absolutely tore up her chest. Every morning when I take my tamoxifen, I think of her...if she had been ER+, would that little pill have kept her alive long enough to see me grow up, graduate from college, become a published writer, etc.? So many questions, so few answers. When my oncologist e-mailed me last weekend to say that my CT scan results came back NED, I thought of my mother first. I think I could hear her sigh of relief all the way from the Other World. You know your children's level of sophistication better than anyone. A lot, too, can depend on the support structure of friends, family, and the community you live in. I've had almost 40 years to ponder my mother's breast cancer and how it affected my life during her illness and after her death, and I still don't have any firm conclusions...except, perhaps, that I wish she had had access to the medical advances available to me during my treatment. I wish you the best of luck with your decision.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2012 09:12AM - edited May 3, 2012 09:13AM by Celtic_Spirit Yeh, that title caught my eye, too! I'm not a Brit, but I've spent enough time there and in New Zealand to know the "other" meaning of that word! And I've been known to refer to obnoxious people locally as "wankers" because they haven't a clue that they've just been insulted! To answer your question, whether people see you as a "huge ball of breast cancer" depends a lot on you. If you talk about it, if you go without a wig, then people are going to feel free to quiz you. I didn't want to be "cancer girl," so I kept the circle very small and wore a wig. I did tell my dentist and hygienist about my bc because I needed to let them know I was on Zometa.Fortunately, their reaction was akin to someone telling them they had a sprained ankle, and no big deal was made. BTW, if you're ever in England and someone tells you that a pub has "good crack," they're not telling you where to get drugs. "Crack" means good conversation, good beer, good all-around atmosphere. I had a friend from England who was a smoker who came to visit a while back. I told him not to go into the neighborhood convenience store and ask for "fags," especially since there was a gay bar just around the corner!

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 02:24PM - edited Feb 16, 2009 02:24PM by Celtic_Spirit I purposely have not told a lot of people about my condition, esp. here at work. While I work with some very kind, sensitive people, there is the knuckle-dragger element who say stupid things and, I'm sure, would be waiting for me to grow a third eye on my forehead or something. Their interest in my condition would only go so far as having something to gossip about. I don't suffer fools gladly, so for everyone's benefit, I kept the number of people "in the know" to a minimum. You have what is known as HIPAA rights...your employer, coworkers, etc. have no right to your personal, medical information. You are under no obligation to share your health information with anyone. For me, I found this to be a blessing.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 01:04PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I really like my oncologist (Dr. D) both as a doctor and a person. The treatment plan she developed for me has been spot on, and I don't think I would have received better care or more advanced treatment if I went to M.D. Anderson. During chemo, I met with her every three weeks, two days before my infusion. During this visit, she would check me out physically, record side effects, put in prescription orders, and thoroughly answer every question I had (usually around two notebook pages worth), even though I'm sure I made her late for her next appointment. And she ends every appointment by giving her patient a hug. She is always available via e-mail for advice, questions, etc., and when I had a staph infection from my chemo port, she called me from her home on her day off. Her style is to be honest, but I think she handles tough questions very diplomatically. Dr. D was very focused and serious during our first meeting. When I later thought about it, I can understand why. Oncologists have to deliver some of the worst news to some of the most vulnerable patients. I'm sure some patients come unglued, are angry, pass out, etc. They never know what to expect when they meet that patient for the first time. Dr. D learned early on that I wasn't the type to wig out on her and that although I lost my boobs, I didn't lose my sense of humor (and yes, I have a bent for gallows humor). She actually has a marvellous sense of humor herself, and we enjoy joking around with each other.

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 12:52PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: Paige, our diagnoses are very similar, and we're both the same age. I also can't imagine that anyone with cancer wouldn't be "anxious." Seems like that goes with the territory, no? I don't know if you've explored any of the "extra" things you can do to lessen your chance of recurrence, such as taking vitamin D-3, Zometa, and exercise. We had a good thread on this forum not long ago about Zometa; you may want to have a read when you get a chance. Cora - I know what you mean about separation anxiety with your onc. Believe me, I was one happy camper when chemo was over, but not seeing my onc every three weeks made me jittery. One of the things that I like to much about her is that she made me feel safe. As corny as it sounds, she was the rock I clung to during my cancer storm...someone strong, someone with the answers, someone who could fix every bad side effect and give me a pep talk every three weeks. I'm fine now, but it is reassuring knowing that she's just an e-mail away.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2012 01:29PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: The first CT scan I had, which was after my bmx and prior to chemo, showed a bunch of small spots on my liver that were "too small to characterize." My onc said the best case scenario would be that they look the same when she scanned me following chemo. Fortunately, that was the case. They may be nerve endings, blood vessels, hemangiomas, etc., but they aren't cancer. Whew! I did spend the six months between CT scans sweating bullets, wondering if I were actually stage IV. Second scare...one day I was scratching my port scar when I felt two pea-sized lumps under the scar. I had an appointment anyway with my primarcy care doctor, so I asked her about them. She said they weren't lymph nodes, but she didn't know what they were. A month later when I saw my onc, she felt them and wasn't sure what they were, so she referred me to a surgeon. The surgeon knew right away...scar tissue had formed around a couple of inner stitches used to close the area where my port was. I've had some sharp pains under my arms and around my port scar, which my onc says are my nerves regenerating and creating new pathways. This could go on for years. Aside from the questionable liver findings, I can't say I get really worked up about these "scares." My approach is to not fret about something until there's a reason to. Worry is like a rocking chair: it keeps you busy, but it doesn't take you anywhere.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2011 06:04PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I'm BRCA negative, but my onc and gyneological onc both thought it would be a good idea because (1) it would eliminate most of the estrogen/progesterine in my body and (2) my mother died of bc and her sister died of ovarian cancer (though at an old age), so they feel there is some sort of genetic component to my cancer, they just don't know what. Both do feel that removing the ovaries is beneficial to preventing bc recurrences. My onc also felt the benefits of an oophorectomy outweighed the risks/side effects for me for several reasons. She said that, at 49, my ovaries had done about all the good they were going to do and, with natural menopause knocking at my door, their usefulness had about expired anyway. Second, my bones are in excellent shape, and I have no family history of osteoporosis; therefore, loss of my ovaries was less likely to have a damaging effect on my bones. I would suggest weighing the benefits/costs of having an oophorectomy based on your own family history and physical attributes and go from there.

I'm also one of those people who did everything right...ate lots of fruits, nuts, and vegetables and avoided fastfood, red meats, highly processed foods, etc.; exercised; took supplements; had a yearly mammogram and physical; etc. However, while "doing everything right" didn't prevent cancer, it has kept me otherwise healthy and strong, which made the rigours of cancer treatment more tolerable than it would have been had I suffered from diabetes, high blood pressure, etc.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2009 02:43AM Celtic_Spirit wrote: My pre-chemo CT scan said almost exactly the same thing: "liver shows small dots that are too small to characterize or biopsy." My onc wasn't worried about them, but I sweated bullets for six months until the followup CT scan. The followup scan revealed that the dots looked the same, which was a VERY good thing. As part of the followup scan, my onc ordered a 3-phase liver study. This was basically a CT scan that took shots of my liver at just about every angle, with and without contrast. Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2010 11:54AM Celtic_Spirit wrote: Barbe - Without getting too indepth, and recognizing that there are many different pagan schools of thought (kind of like Catholics, Baptists, Episcopalians, and Mormans), here are a few Yule traditions that we can see in how Christmas is celebrated today: In ancient times, in the northern countries of Europe, animals were brought in from the high meadows as winter approached. Because fodder was scarce, only the strongest and finest beasts were kept. The others were killed and, because citizens of the Dark Ages didn't have refrigerators, the meat had to be consumed or dried quickly. This called for a feast.  People often exchanged gifts of meat or other food they had grown, or linens they had woven, soap they had made, etc.  Thus we have the prototype of our basic Christmas morning get-togethers celebrated today. People would visit each other's homes to exchange goods, and they were often served a strong, hot drink or ale. They would toast the host and say "waes hael," which is Old English for "be hale." Recognize that word? We know know it as "wassail." Yule fell during midwinter, the darkest time of the year. To encourage the return of the sun, fires were lit (think, today, candles and Yule logs). Pagans think very circular, and the year is seen as a "wheel." The Druids of Britain would bless a log and keep it burning for 12 days during the winter solstice (how often does "12" show up in regards to Christmas?). Part of this log was preserved for the following year, with it would be used to light the new log, thus completing a wheel or circle. Today, we often hear Christmas referred to as "the season of light" or "the celebration of light." The boar  (Boar's Head) was a favorite dish, as the boar was a solar animal, having bristles of gold like the rays of the sun. Today, many people serve ham as their Christmas dish. The ancient Celts and Norse also cherished evergreens, esp. at this time of year, as they are the natural symbol of rebirth and life amid winter's whiteness. Today, we decorate with pine trees and holly.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 11:44PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: There seems to be two schools of thought: to scan or not to scan. I've read...and my oncologist agrees...that success in treating a distant recurrence doesn't depend on catching it early. If the cancer is going to respond to treatment, it'll respond whether the lesion is 3mm or 3 cm. Personally, I'm torn on how I feel about this. I'm very much a "nip it in the bud" kind of person. I fix the car the minute I hear a rattle; I don't wait until the rattle becomes a roar and then end up broken down on the side of the road. Same with my body. On the other hand, waiting for scan results makes me looney, so I'd rather not have the additional anxiety...and exposure to radiation...every few months. As I mentioned, my onc doesn't do routine scans unless you present with symptoms. My insurance is with Kaiser, and since they have their own treatment centers, scanning equipment, techs, and doctors, I don't think they save much money if they don't scan. How they decide may have something to do with how aggressive they consider a person's cancer or the philosophy they were taught in med school. My onc has mentioned there's "East Coast and West Coast" schools of thought with oncology. I don't remember her explanation (it was our first meeting; my head was spinning), but perhaps this has something to do with it. Yes, the risk for recurrence is greatest during the first two years.

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 12:37PM - edited Nov 23, 2009 12:38PM by Celtic_Spirit When I was a little kid, I remember my dad watching football games with his friends on Thanksgiving after dinner. They would put their beers on TV trays, and I'd slither underneath the trays, nip the beer can off the tray and take a sip when I thought they weren't watching! My dad thought this was hilarious, but my mom wasn't amused. LOL! When I was a teenager living with my foster mom in Tennessee, I remember getting out of bed Thanksgiving morning to use the restroom. I walked into the living room, and it was filled wall-to-wall with folk musicians, including John McCutcheon. I blinked several times and walked back into my bedroom and got back into bed. I thought I had dreamed the whole thing. She made the biggest breakfast I've ever seen that morning - biscuits, gravy, grits, bacon, eggs, toast, pancakes, sausage - for everyone there. When I was in college, I got a hankering for Thanksgiving dishes one April. I thought, why not have Thanksgiving several times a year? There's no law saying you can have turkey and dressing and cranberry sauce only once a year in November! So I bought a turkey and made the whole meal and invited my best friend over for dinner. That was almost 30 years ago, and she still talks about the time we had Thanksgiving in April!

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2009 09:21PM - edited Jul 13, 2009 09:22PM by Celtic_Spirit Beesie, I looked at the table you provided the link for. That data is from 1989, which is like the Stone Age in the oncology world. Data that old might scare the bejezus out of recently diagnosed ladies. Since 1989, chemotherapy has come a long way, including the introduction of the taxanes and Herceptin. I'm not sure if tamoxifen was available in 1989 (and for the women in this study, many years prior to 1989), but the AIs were yet to appear on the scene. Radiation wasn't nearly as advanced as it is today. A member of my hospital's tumor board said not to pay attention to any cancer data more than five years old, three years preferably. Things have improved so much since 1989. I'm really rather shocked that Komen would have such outdated information on their site.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2013 10:34AM Celtic_Spirit wrote: Similar to you, I was diagnosed in February 2008 at age 48. I had bmx, chemo, and radiation as well. My onc prescribed four rounds of zometa...every six months for two years. My bone density study was done in spring 2009 after zometa infusion #1, and my onc said my bones were in "great shape." I haven't had a bone density (or any other scan) done since. I, too, started off on tamoxifen (2 years) and then switched to Arimidex in December 2010. I'm rather curious about how much Arimidex has affected my bones. My onc use to check blood work every six months during my first year after chemo. Now I have neither scans nor blood work. I'm glad I don't have scans...I can do without an added dose of anxiety every six months. I don't know why some oncologists scan/do blood work and others don't. Maybe it's the hospital's/medical group's protocol or maybe personal preference. When I asked my onc about anniversary dates, she said that there's no firm consensus on it, but perhaps I should consider it to be some time around the beginning of my treatment. I chose the date of my mastectomy (March 25), since that's the day cancer left the building!

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2012 04:39PM - edited Sep 7, 2012 04:39PM by Celtic_Spirit I had a bmx, so no yearly mammograms for me. I have follow up visits with my oncologist twice a year. During the first 1-2 years, I had CBCs and liver function tests done before each visit, and because I was receiving zometa, I also had renal function tests. She tested my cholesterol before taking Arimidex and six months after to see if it had risen. I turned 50 at the tail end of active treatment, and my gynelogical oncologist ordered a bone density test as part of the "turning 50" thing my HMO does. Now, during my follow up appointments, my oncologist asks about symptoms and if I'm still exercising, and then she manually pokes around my chest, underarms, and abdomen. Mostly we chew the fat about vacations, iPads, and cross-stitch. There's really not much for her to do during these visits...my blood work reverted to normal pretty quickly, I'm not experiencing any problems, and other than Arimidex, I'm not receiving any treatment.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 11:08PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I breezed through bi-lat mastectomy and chemo, then felt like I hit a brick wall with radiation. I never truly knew what tired was before because I'm such a high-energy person. However, I managed to work full-time, run errands, socialize, etc. I just hit the sack at night around 8:30-9:00 instead of my usual 10:30. However, the tiredness, for me, didn't come on until about week 4 of 6. My radiation onc kept asking, "Aren't you tired yet?" I finally said, "No, you'll just have to try harder!" LOL! That's what I get for being sassy! But a month later, I felt worlds better, and I'm back to my usual monkey business. Rads may not be as hard for you...I had other things going on at the same time that probably worsened my fatigue (starting Tamoxifen, a staph infection, Zometa infusion, sinus crud). I've known women who experienced no fatigue.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 01:28PM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I'm sure there's a lot of variance between clinics and rad oncs, but here's what happened at my first appt. I met with the radiation onc, she went over the plan she created for me and why she was recommending what she did; we talked about my general health, skin care, diet, and what to expect from treatment (i.e., possible side effects); she examined my surgical sites and told me everything looked good. She told me I would meet with her weekly, and she answered the questions I had at that time. Scans - yes, they do some sort of low-level CT scan so they can get your positioning tattoos correct (probably for other reasons too; doesn't involve drinking anything nasty or getting an injection). During the first five or so treatments, they did xrays (I guess to see if they were hitting their marks). For me, it wasn't a bad experience. My rad onc was very nice and professional, and I don't remember her saying anything discouraging. The techs were great and fun to joke with.

Posts.Title: Questions re: Shingles justjudie justjudie

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2014 01:59AM Celtic_Spirit wrote: I hope you don't mind me commenting, but I saw the topic and have some experience (unfortunately) with this subject. I had shingles about 12 years ago (pre-cancer). Mine started like yours, on my back, and then under my breast, almost forming half a band around my torso. It was a pain that hurt clear through my body, from my back through to my front. As it progressed and I broke out in small blisters (like chicken pox), it hurt, ached, and itched at the same time. Ugh. There's about a 72-hour window during which you should get meds. After that, they aren't as effective. My symptoms started on a Saturday, and I managed to scoot into the doctor's office just in time. For pain, my doctor gave me a drug that in higher doses is used as an anti-psychotic. It may have been nortriptyline, but I'm not sure. She also gave me something to combat the virus. The pain and blisters lasted 8-14 days. I still had some nerve pain in the arm nearest to the rash, but that resolved over a few months. I don't have any permanent damage from shingles. Ask your doctor if cold compresses might help the pain and itching. Also ask about getting a pain killer in the class that treats referred pain (tricyclics, I believe), such as nortriptyline. These drugs and others are used to treat sciatica and fibromyalgia and may work better than morphine or Dilaudid. I hope this helped. Take care of yourself.
